statement.p: A curve is a set of points such that for every point in the set, the set locally looks like a (possibly bent or curved) copy of the real line \mathbb R or the half line \mathbb R^*=\{x\in\mathbb R:x\geq 0\}.
Two objects are said to be topologically equivalent or homeomorphic if one may be bent or stretched into the shape of the other.

A surface is a set of points such that for every point in the set, the set locally looks like a (possibly bent or curved) copy of the plane \mathbb R^2 or the half-plane \mathbb R^{2*}=\{\tuple{x,y}\in\mb R^2:x\geq 0\}.
Let a,b\in\mb R. The open interval from a to b is the set
Let x\in\mb R and S\subseteq\mb R. The point x is a limit point of the set S if and only if for every open interval (a,b) containing x, there is a point y\in S such that x\not=y and y\in(a,b).
A subset U\subseteq\mb R is called open if and only if for every point x\in U, there exists an open interval (a,b) such that x\in(a,b)\subseteq U.
A subset U\subseteq\mb R is open if and only if there exists a collection of open intervals \mc U such that U=\bigcup\mc U.
The open subsets of \mb R satisfy the following properties.

ol.li: \emptyset and \mb R are open sets.
If \mc U is a collection of open sets, then \bigcup\mc U is also an open set.
If U,V are open sets, then U\cap V is an open set.

statement.p: Let X be a set, and let \mc T\subseteq \mc P(X) satisfy the following properties.

ol.li: \emptyset,X\in\mc T.
If \mc U\subseteq\mc T, then \bigcup\mc U\in\mc T.
If U,V\in\mc T, then U\cap V\in\mc T.

statement.p: Then \mc T is called a topology on X, the pair \tuple{X,\mc T} is called a topological space, and elements U\in\mc T are called open sets of the space. (Usually \tuple{X,\mc T} is abbreviated to just X when the topology is known from context.)
Let \mc T\subseteq\mc P(\mb R) be the collection of open subsets of \mb R defined by . Then by , \mc T is a valid topology for \mb R called the Euclidean topology.
Let X be any set. Then the following sets are topologies on X.

ol.li: \mc T=\mc P(X) is called the discrete topology.
\mc T=\{\emptyset,X\} is called the indiscrete topology.

statement.p: Let a,b\in\mb R\cup\setList{-\infty,\infty}. The following are called intervals of real numbers.
Let \tuple{X,\mc T} be a topological space and let x\in X. The set N\subseteq X is called a neighborhood of x if and only if there exists an open set U\in\mc T such that x\in U\subseteq N.
The following are known as separation axioms for a topological space \tuple{X,\mc T}.

ol.li:
\mc T is said to be T_0 if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x
ot=y, there either exists a neighborhood U of x such that y
ot\in U, or there exists a neighborhood V of y such that x
ot\in V.
\mc T is said to be T_1 if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x\not=y, there exists a neighborhood U of x such that y\not\in U.
\mc T is said to be T_2 (also known as Hausdorff) if and only if for all points x,y\in X such that x\not=y, there exist neighborhoods U,V of x,y (respectively) such that U\cap V=\emptyset.

statement.p: Let X be a finite topological space. Then X is T_1 if and only if X has the discrete topology.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. The point x is a limit point of the set S if and only if for every neighborhood of U of x, there is a point y\in S such that x\not=y and y\in U.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then S' is the set of all limit points of S, called the derived set of S.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then \cl S=S\cup S' is called the closure of S.
Let H\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then H is called closed if and only if H=\cl S.
Let H\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. Then H is closed if and only if there exists an open set U such that H=X\setminus U.
A topological space X is T_1 if and only if every finite subset of X is closed.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. The point x is a boundary point of the set S if and only if for every neighborhood of U of x, both U\cap S and U\setminus S are non-empty.
Let \bd S collect all the boundary points of S.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. The point x is a interior point of the set S if and only if there exists a neighborhood U of x such that x\in U\subseteq S.
Let \int S collect all the interior points of S.
Let S\subseteq X be a subset of a topological space. The point x is a exterior point of the set S if and only if there exists a neighborhood U of x such that x\in U\subseteq X\setminus S.
Let \ext S collect all the exterior points of S.
A partition of a set X is a collection \mc P such that X=\bigcup\mc P and A\cap B=\emptyset for all A,B\in\mc P where A\not=B.
A subset D\subseteq X of a topological space is called dense if and only if \cl D=X.
A subset D of a topological space is dense if and only if every nonempty open set of the space contains a point of D.
Let Y\subseteq X for a topological space \tuple{X,\mc T}. Then the subspace topology for Y is given by \mc T_Y=\setBuilder{U\cap Y}{U\in\mc T}.

The Cantor set is the subset C\subseteq\mb R defined by C=\bigcap_{n\in\mb N} C_n, where C_0=[0,1] and C_{n+1}=C_n\setminus\bigcup_{0\leq k\lt 3^n} \left(\frac{3k+1}{3^{n+1}},\frac{3k+2}{3^{n+1}}\right). This set is usually considered as a closed subset of the Euclidean line, or as a subspace of the Euclidean line.

Let \tuple{X,\mc T} be a topological space. A subset \mc B\subseteq\mc T is called a basis for the topology if for every x\in X and neighborhood U of x, there exists B\in\mc B such that x\in B\subseteq U.
Let \mc B\subseteq\mc P(X) satisfy the following properties:

ol.li: For all x\in X, there exists B\in\mc B such that x\in B.
If x\in A\in\mc B and x\in B\in\mc B, there exists C\in\mc B such that x\in C\subseteq A\cap B.

statement.p: Then \mc T=\setBuilder{\bigcup\mc U}{\mc U\subseteq\mc B} is a topology, and \mc B is a basis for that topology. We call this the topology generated by the basis.
Let \mc S\subseteq\mc P(X) and \mc T=\bigcap\setBuilder{\mc T^\star\subseteq\mc P(X)}{\mc S\subseteq\mc T^\star \text{ and } \mc T^\star \text{ is a topology on } X}. Then \mc T is a topology.

The set \mc S\subseteq\mc P(X) in is called a subbasis generating the topology \mc T=\bigcap\setBuilder{\mc T^\star\subseteq\mc P(X)}{\mc S\subseteq\mc T^\star \text{ and } \mc T^\star \text{ is a topology on } X}.
The following are also known as separation axioms for a topological space \tuple{X,\mc T}.

ol.li: \mc T is said to be regular if and only if for all points x\in X and closed subsets H\subseteq X such that x\not\in H, there exist open sets U,V\in\mc T such that x\in U,H\subseteq V,U\cap V=\emptyset.
\mc T is said to be T_3 if and only if it is both regular and T_1
\mc T is said to be normal if and only if for all closed subsets H,L\subseteq X such that H\cap L=\emptyset, there exist open sets U,V\in\mc T such that H\subseteq U,L\subseteq V,U\cap V=\emptyset.
\mc T is said to be T_4 if and only if it is both normal and T_1

statement.p: The real line \mb R equipped with the Euclidean topology is T_4.
A topological space is T_3 if and only if it is regular and T_0.

Let f:X\to Y be a function. For A\subseteq X, let f[A]=\setBuilder{f(x)}{x\in A}. For y\in Y, let f^\leftarrow(y)=\setBuilder{x\in X}{f(x)=y}. For B\subseteq Y, let f^\leftarrow[B]=\setBuilder{x\in X}{f(x)\in B}.

Let X,Y be topological spaces with x\in X, and let f:X\to Y be a function such that for every neighborhood V of f(x), there exists a neighborhood U of x such that f[U]\subseteq V. Then f is said to be continuous at the point x.
A function that is continuous at every point of its domain is called continuous.
If f:X\to Y and g:Y\to Z are both continuous, then g\circ f:X\to Z is continuous.
Let f:X\to Y be a bijection such that both f and its inverse f^{-1} are continuous. Then f is called a homeomorphism and X,Y are said to be homeomorphic.
Let a\lt b and c\lt d be real numbers. Then (a,b) and (c,d) are homeomorphic subspaces of the Euclidean line.
\mb R with the Euclidean topology is homeomorphic to its subspace (0,1).

Let \mc B be a basis for the Euclidean topology on \mb R. Give K=\mb R\cup\setList{-\infty,\infty} the topology generated by the basis \setBuilder{[-\infty,x)}{x\in\mb Q}\cup \setBuilder{(x,\infty]}{x\in\mb Q}\cup\mc B. Then K is homeomorphic to the subspace [0,1] of the Euclidean line.
Let d:X^2\to[0,\infty) be a function satisfying the following for all x,y,z\in X.

ol.li: d(x,y)=0 if and only if x=y.

statement.p: Then d is said to be a metric on the set X, and B_r(x)=\setBuilder{y\in X}{d(x,y)\lt r} is said to be a metric ball around x.
The topology generated by the basis given in is called the topology generated by the metric.
A given topology is said to be metrizable if there exists some metric that generates it. Two metrics are said to be topologically equivalent if they generate the same topology.
Every metrizable space is T_4.

Two bases \mc B_0,\mc B_1 generate the same topology if and only if for all x\in B_0\in\mc B_0 there exists B_1\in\mc B_1 such that x\in B_1\subseteq B_0, and for all x\in B_1\in\mc B_1 there exists B_0\in\mc B_0 such that x\in B_0\subseteq B_1.

Let B_{0,r}(x),B_{1,r}(x) be the metric balls around x given by two metrics d_0,d_1 respectively. Then d_0,d_1 are topologically equivalent if and only if for all x\in X and \epsilon\gt 0, there exists \delta\gt 0 such that B_{0,\delta}(x)\subseteq B_{1,\epsilon} and B_{1,\delta}(x)\subseteq B_{0,\epsilon}(x).
For \vec x=\tuple{x_0,\dots,x_{n-1}}\in\mb R^n, let \vec x(i)=x_i.
The following metrics on \mb R^n are topologically equivalent.

li.m: d(\vec x,\vec y)=\sqrt{\sum_{0\leq i\lt n}(\vec y(i)-\vec x(i))^2}
d(\vec x,\vec y)=\sum_{0\leq i\lt n}|\vec y(i)-\vec x(i)|
d(\vec x,\vec y)=\max\setBuilder{|\vec y(i)-\vec x(i)|}{0\leq i\lt n}

statement.p: The topology generated by the metrics given in is called the Euclidean topology on \mb R^n.
A local basis at a point x is a collection of open sets \mc B_x such that for every neighborhood U of x, there exists B\in\mc B_x such that x\in B_x\subseteq U.
A space is said to be first-countable if there exists a countable local basis at every point of the space.
A space is said to be second-countable if there exists a countable basis for the space.
A space is said to be separable if there exists a countable dense subset of the space.
Let X be metrizable. Then X is second-countable if and only if it is separable.

For \vec x,\vec y\in\mb R^2, let d(\vec x,\vec y)=1 if \vec x(1)\not=\vec y(1), and d(\vec x,\vec y)=|\vec y(0)-\vec x(0)| otherwise. Then d is a metric generating a non-separable, non-discrete topology on \mb R^2.
The subspace \setBuilder{\vec x}{\vec{x}(1)\in\setList{0,1}} of the space defined in is homeomorphic to the subspace (0,1)\cup(2,3) of the Euclidean line.

A point x is called a sequential limit point of a set A iff there exists a countable subset B\subseteq A\setminus\setList{x} such that every neighborhood of x contains all but finitely many points of B.
Let X be first-countable. Then x is a limit point of a set if and only if x is a sequental limit point of that set.
A Cauchy sequence is a countably infinte set A such that for all \epsilon\gt0, the set \setBuilder{x\in A}{\exists y\in A(d(x,y)\geq\epsilon)} is finite.
A complete metric is a metric such that every Cauchy sequence has a sequential limit point.
A topology that can be generated by a complete metric is said to be completely metrizable.
The subspace (0,1) of the Euclidean line is completely metrizable, but not by the topology inherited from \mb R.
The subspace \mb Q of the Euclidean line is metrizable, but not completely metrizable.
The subspace \mb R\setminus\mb Q of the Euclidean line is completely metrizable, but not by the topology inherited from \mb R.
Metrizable and completely metrizable are topological properties. That is, if X and Y are homeomorphic, then X is (completely) metrizable if and only if Y is too.
A collection \mc A\subseteq \mc P(X) is said to cover a subset Y\subseteq X iff Y\subseteq\bigcup\mc A.
A subset K\subseteq X of a topological space is said to be compact iff for every collection of open sets \mc U covering K, there exists a finite subcollection \mc F\subseteq\mc U that also covers K.

A subset R\subseteq X of a topological space is said to be relatively compact iff for every collection of open sets \mc U covering X, there exists a finite subcollection \mc F\subseteq\mc U that covers K.
A space is regular if and only if for every point x and neighborhood U, there exists a neighborhood V of x such that x\in V\subseteq\cl V\subseteq U.
Let X be regular. A subset R\subseteq X is relatively compact if and only if \cl R is compact.
Let X be compact and K be a closed subset of X. Then K is compact.
Every compact subset of a Hausdorff space is closed.
Let f:X\to Y be continuous and K\subseteq X be compact. Then f[K] is compact.
Every infinite subset of a compact set has a limit point.

Let \mc K=\setBuilder{K_n}{n\in\mb N} be a collection of non-empty compact subsets of a topological space such that K_{n+1}\subseteq K_n for all n\in\mb N. Then \bigcap\mc K is a non-empty compact set.
Let X be metrizable. Then the following are equivalent for K\subseteq X.

ol.li: K is compact
Every infinite subset of K has a limit point.
Every infinite subset of K has a sequential limit point.

statement.p: Every compact Hausdorff space is T_4.

A pair of open sets \setList{A,B} satisfying A\cap Y\not=\emptyset, B\cap Y\not=\emptyset, Y\subseteq A\cup B, and A\cap B\cap Y=\emptyset for a subset Y of a topological space X is called a disconnection of Y.
A space for which a diconnection exists is called disconnected; otherwise, the space is called connected.
The Sorgenfrey topology on \mb R is disconnected.
If a subset A of a topological space is connected, then \cl A is connected.
If \mc A is a collection of connected subsets of a topological space with \bigcap\mc A\not=\emptyset, then \bigcup\mc A is connected.
Suppose for every two points x,y\in A\subseteq X, there exists a continuous function f:[0,1]\to A such that f(0)=x and f(1)=y. Such a space is said to be path connected.

For \vec x,\vec y\in\mb R^2, let B(\vec x,\vec y)=\setBuilder{\vec z}{\vec z(0)\in(\vec x(0),\vec y(0)) \text{ or } (\vec x(0)=\vec y(0)=\vec z(0) \text{ and } \vec z(1)\in(\vec x(1),\vec y(1))}. Then \mc B=\setBuilder{B(\vec x,\vec y)}{\vec x,\vec y\in\mb R^2} is a basis for a topology on \mb R^2 that is connected but not path connected.

Let X,Y be topological spaces, generated respectively by the bases \mc B_X,\mc B_Y. Then the product space is given by the set X\times Y=\setBuilder{\tuple{x,y}}{x\in X,y\in Y} with the topology generated by the basis \mc B=\setBuilder{U\times V}{U\in\mc B_X,V\in\mc B_Y}.
The Euclidean space \mb R^{n+1} is homeomorphic to the product space \mb R^n\times\mb R.
The product X\times Y is regular if and only if X,Y are each regular.
Let S=\mb R equipped with the Sorgenfrey topology. Then S is normal, but S\times S is not normal.
For a product space X\times Y, its projection maps \pi_X:X\times Y\to X and \pi_Y:X\times Y\to Y are defined by \pi_X(\tuple{x,y})=x and \pi_Y(\tuple{x,y})=y.
The product X\times Y is metrizable if and only if X,Y are each metrizable.
The product X\times Y is compact if and only if X,Y are each compact.
The product X\times Y is connected if and only if X,Y are each connected.
A quotient map is a surjection f:X\to Y such that V\subseteq Y is open if and only if f^\leftarrow[V]\subseteq X is open.
The topology defined in is known as the quotient topology induced by f.

Let X^* be a partition of a topological space X, and let f:X\to X^* be the surjection given by letting f(x)=A iff x\in A. Then X^* paired with the quotient topology induced by f is called a quotient space or identification space.
Let X^* be a quotient space of X and V\subseteq X^*. Then V is open in X^* if and only if \bigcup V\subseteq X is open in X.
Let (X\times Y)^*=\setBuilder{\setList{x}\times Y}{x\in X} partition the product X\times Y. Then the quotient space (X\times Y)^* is homeomorphic to X.
A subset R\subseteq X^2 is called a relation on X, where the notation xRy is equivalent to writing \tuple{x,y}\in R.
A relation \sim on X is called an equivalence relation if it satisfies the following for all x,y,z\in X.

ol.li: x\sim x. (Reflexivity)
x\sim y implies y\sim x. (Symmetry)
x\sim y and y\sim z implies y\sim z. (Transitivity)

statement.p: Let X^* be a partition of X and define the relation \sim on X such that x\sim y if and only if \setList{x,y}\subseteq A for some A\in X^*. Then \sim is an equivalence relation.
Let \sim be an equivalence relation on X, and let [x]=\setBuilder{y\in X}{x\sim y}. Then X^*=\setBuilder{[x]}{x\in X} is a partition of X.
Let \sim be an equivalence relation on a topological space X. Then X/\sim denotes the quotient space defined by the partition X^* given in .
The hypersphere of dimension n is the quotient space S^n=[0,1]^n/\sim given by \vec x\sim\vec y whenever there exist i,j\in\setList{0,\dots,n} such that \vec x(i),\vec y(j)\in\setList{0,1}.
The Möbius strip is the quotient space M=[0,1]^2/\sim given by \tuple{0,y}\sim\tuple{1,1-y}.
The torus is the quotient space T=[0,1]^2/\sim given by \tuple{0,y}\sim\tuple{1,y} and \tuple{x,0}\sim\tuple{x,1}.
The Klein bottle is the quotient space K=[0,1]^2/\sim given by \tuple{0,y}\sim\tuple{1,1-y} and \tuple{x,0}\sim\tuple{x,1}.
